subject: ACCT
title: Financial Accounting
description: Contemporary accounting and corporate financial reporting. Preparation, interpretation, and analysis of the earnings statement; the statement of financial position; and the statement of cash flows. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: AFAM
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Black Power and Black Panthers in the 1960s
description: The development of African American political activism and political theory from 1960 to 1972, with a focus on student movements. Agitation for civil rights and social equality traced through the history and political agendas of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and the Black Panther Party. How key members of these organizations created policies and platforms that were meant to empower people of African descent in a way that the civil rights movement did not. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: AFAM
title: CANCELLED
description: Chronological and thematic issues related to the creation, analysis, and collecting of African American art. Introduction to the field of African American art through close engagement with archival sources and art objects held in the Yale University Art Gallery and the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library. Methodologies used to write about art in both African American studies and art history; collecting and museum practices; the relationships between art, artists, and community formations. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: AFAM
title: CANCELLED
description: From the garreting of Harriet Jacobs to Tyler Perry as Madea, this course introduces students to applied religious ethics through an exploration of black faith and sexuality in the United States. Students will learn basic foundational models for understanding religious ethics in philosophical, theological, and social terms while engaging the intersections of race, gender, sexuality, and faith. This course explores ethical frameworks functioning within cultural theory, historical accounts, film, and works of fiction. Students will be guided in a consideration of the roles of creativity and imagination in the formations of race, faith, and sexuality. Topics include sexual violence and exploitation, respectability and the black family, reclaiming the erotic, and new spiritualities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: AFAM
title: Race,Politics&Schools1940-2010
description: The culture and politics of school desegregation from the decade before the  Brown v. Board of Education decision to the present. The iconic desegregation crises in Little Rock and New Orleans and the politics of memory and historical narrative. Issues of race and public education, American democracy, contemporary trends of resegregation, and the abandonment of integration as a strategy in education reform. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: AFAM
title: MulticulturalismOrderedSociety
description: Is there a link between social identity and crime?  What is the relationship among race, gender and perceptions of criminality?  What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime and criminal justice policy?  This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime and the criminal justice system.  Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories and debates.  Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration and unequal justice.  Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: AFAM
title: CANCELLED
description: Theoretical, methodological, and aesthetic models in the field of critical ethnography, which seeks to understand and illustrate lived experiences of subjects who are differently situated in social webs of power. Models drawn mostly from race theory, postcolonial theory, queer theory, and feminisms. Problems of methodology, ethics, politics, and poetics that have an impact on students' own research practice. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: AFST
title: CANCELLED
description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Survey of the modern history of East Africa, with a focus on health, environment, and society. The rise of Swahili language and culture; slavery and plantation agriculture; colonial regimes, medical discourse, and environmental degradation; agrarian protest and nationalist mobilization; conservation ethics and national parks; female genital cutting; HIV/AIDS. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Mombasa, costs of room and board in Mombasa, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Yale students may petition for one HU area credit. Tuition: $5,800. Course Dates: June 25 - August 6.

subject: AFST
title: IslamicSocietyCulture&Politics
description: The historical development of the global Muslim community, from its origins in seventh-century Arabia through its spread over subsequent centuries into the Middle East, Africa, Central and South/Southeast Asia, and the West. The tremendous variation and complexity expressed in society, culture, and politics across the Islamic world; Islam as a unifying factor on critical issues such as religious practice, political structure and activism, gender, and cultural expression. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: AMST
title: Modern American Literature
description: A survey of American literature and culture in the first half of the twentieth century. Works by Ernest Hemingway, T.S. Eliot, Ezra Pound, William Carlos Williams, Muriel Rukeyser, Nella Larsen, Langston Hughes, and William Faulkner. Please see online syllabus for readings for the first day of class. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: AMST
title: MulticulturalismOrderedSociety
description: Is there a link between social identity and crime?  What is the relationship among race, gender and perceptions of criminality?  What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime and criminal justice policy?  This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime and the criminal justice system.  Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories and debates.  Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration and unequal justice.  Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: AMST
title: Hollywd Novel & Hollywd Movie
long_title: The Hollywood Novel and the Hollywood Movie
description: A survey of the histories of both the Hollywood novel and films about Hollywood. Examination of the ways in which these two genres portray "the dream factory" - its past, its present, and its future - as well as the way they interact. Books include Harry Leon Wilson's Merton at the Movies, Horace McCoy's They Shoot Horses, Don't They? and I Should Have Stayed Home, F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Last Tycoon, Budd Schulberg's What Makes Sammy Run, and Gore Vidal's Myra Breckenridge. Films include What Price Hollywood? A Star Is Born, Sunset Boulevard, In a Lonely Place, The Star, and The Player. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: AMST
title: Race,Politics&Schools1940-2010
description: The culture and politics of school desegregation from the decade before the  Brown v. Board of Education decision to the present. The iconic desegregation crises in Little Rock and New Orleans and the politics of memory and historical narrative. Issues of race and public education, American democracy, contemporary trends of resegregation, and the abandonment of integration as a strategy in education reform. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: AMST
title: Film, Video & American History
description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment.  This course seeks to expand its students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture and society.  In-class screenings will include The Birth of a Nation, Scarface, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Apocalypse Now, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ANTH
title: Intro-Cultural Anthropology
description: An introduction to the central ideas, methods, and debates that make up the anthropological study of human behavior and societies.  The course surveys the dynamic ways of life in many different societies and considers the ways in which anthropologists try to understand the diversity of social and cultural processes and phenomena.  Hands-on ethnographic research provides insight into anthropological fieldwork, and the tools and techniques used for research and analysis. Film screenings meet W 8-10pm. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ANTH
title: Intro Biological Anthropology
description: Introduction to human and primate evolution, primate behavior, and human biology. Topics include a review of principles of evolutionary and population biology, the evolution of primates and people, and current thinking about the evolution of human behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ANTH
title: Forensic Anthropology
description: Hands-on introduction to forensic anthropology, using laboratory training, lectures, and case studies. Introduction to basic skeletal anatomy and to the use of recovered skeletal materials to assess a deceased individual's age, sex, height, ancestry, time of death, bone trauma, and disease. Additional topics include techniques for recovering human skeletal remains, reconstruction of faces, genetic identification, and medicolegal contexts of forensic anthropology. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ANTH
title: Genesis&CollapseOfOldWorldCivs
long_title: The Genesis and Collapse of Old World Civilizations
description: The archaeology of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley from early agriculture to class formation and the early cities and empires. How did these societies develop and why did they collapse? Earliest epics and contemporary ideologies, including the Bushes in Baghdad, examined in literature and film. Readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ANTH
title: CANCELLED
description: Cultural and historic constructions of masculinity explored through an investigation of male bodies, sexualities, and social interactions. Multiple masculinities; the relationship between hegemonic, nonhegemonic, and subordinate masculinities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ANTH
title: Reproductive Technologies
description: Introduction to scholarship on the anthropology of reproduction. Focus on reproductive technologies such as contraceptives, prenatal diagnostics, childbirth technologies, abortion, assisted reproduction, and reproductive technologies that engender harm, such as sex selection and female circumcision. The globalization of reproductive technologies, including social, cultural, legal, and ethical responses. Recommended preparation: ANTH 110b or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ANTH
title: Archeaology Method and Theory
description: Offered in Turkey. Introduction to basic archaeological method and theory, with hands-on experience in field and laboratory work. Includes an introduction to Anatolian and Near Eastern prehistory and modern Turkish culture.  Must be taken in conjunction with ANTH S278/ARCG S278. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Turkey, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact archaeology.fieldschool@yale.edu. Undergraduates will recieve 2 credits for both courses.  Tuition: $2,900. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ANTH
title: Archeaological Field Tech Lab
description: Offered in Turkey. Introduction to basic archaeological method and theory, with hands-on experience in field and laboratory work. Includes an introduction to Anatolian and Near Eastern prehistory and modern Turkish culture.  Must be taken in conjunction with ANTH S277/ARCG S277. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Turkey, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact archaeology.fieldschool@yale.edu. Undergraduates will recieve 2 credits for both courses. Tuition: $2,900. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ANTH
title: CANCELLED
description: Offered in Tokyo, Japan. Exploration of animation (anime) and graphic novels (manga) in contemporary Japan. Special attention to the social and historical contexts of the production and consumption of manga and anime and to themes of gender and sexuality found within. Includes visits to animation and manga studios and museums, fan conventions, the Cosplay scene, and Kyoto. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session B: July 2 - August 6.

subject: ANTH
title: Bombay:City, SocietyandCulture
description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Critical introduction to contemporary Indian politics, society, culture, and religion through immersive study in Mumbai. Topics include urbanization, poverty, migration, housing, communal violence, caste segregation, class ghettoization, and popular culture. Must be taken in conjunction with SAST S364/LING S119. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from India, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,900. Session A: May 28- July 2.

subject: ANTH
title: CANCELLED
description: Theoretical, methodological, and aesthetic models in the field of critical ethnography, which seeks to understand and illustrate lived experiences of subjects who are differently situated in social webs of power. Models drawn mostly from race theory, postcolonial theory, queer theory, and feminisms. Problems of methodology, ethics, politics, and poetics that have an impact on students' own research practice. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: APHY
title: Science of Modern Technology
description: Examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: APHY
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ARBC
title: Elem Modern Stndrd Arabic I
description: Development of a basic knowledge of Modern Standard Arabic through a comprehensive and integrated method emphasizing reading, writing, speaking, comprehension, grammar, and vocabulary acquisition. Credit only on completion of ARBC S120. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ARBC
title: Elem Modern Stndrd Arabic II
description: Continuation of ARBC S110. Prerequisite: ARBC S110, 110a or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ARBC
title: CANCELLED
description: First part of an intensive language course in New Haven and Amman, Jordan. Intensive review of grammar; readings from contemporary and classical Arab authors with emphasis on serial reading of unvoweled Arabic texts, prose composition, and formal conversation. Must be taken in conjunction with ARBC S140. Prerequisite: ARBC 120 or equivalent. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: ARBC
title: CANCELLED
description: Offered in Amman, Jordan. Continuation of ARBC S130. Prerequisite: ARBC 130. Students are responsible for travel expenses to and from Amman, room and board costs in Jordan, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: ARBC
title: CANCELLED
description: A basic course in the Iraqi/Gulf dialect of Arabic. Principles of grammar and syntax, foundations for conversation and listening comprehension. Prerequisite: ARBC 130a or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tution: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ARCG
title: Genesis&CollapseOfOldWorldCivs
long_title: The Genesis and Collapse of Old World Civilizations
description: The archaeology of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley from early agriculture to class formation and the early cities and empires. How did these societies develop and why did they collapse? Earliest epics and contemporary ideologies, including the Bushes in Baghdad, examined in literature and film. Readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ARCG
title: Archaeology Method and Theory
description: Offered in Turkey. Introduction to basic archaeological method and theory, with hands-on experience in field and laboratory work. Includes an introduction to Anatolian and Near Eastern prehistory and modern Turkish culture.  Must be taken in conjunction with ANTH S278/ARCG S278. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Turkey, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact archaeology.fieldschool@yale.edu. Undergraduates will receive 2 credits for both courses.  Tuition: $2,900. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ARCG
title: Archaeological Field Tech Lab
description: Offered in Turkey. Introduction to basic archaeological method and theory, with hands-on experience in field and laboratory work. Includes an introduction to Anatolian and Near Eastern prehistory and modern Turkish culture.  Must be taken in conjunction with ANTH S277/ARCG S277. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Turkey, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact archaeology.fieldschool@yale.edu. Undergraduates will receive 2 credits for both courses. Tuition: $2,900. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ARCH
title: Visualization I

subject: ARCH
title: Visualization IV: Processing

subject: ARCH
title: Rome: Continuity & Change

subject: ARCH
title: Chinese House Courtyard toCity
long_title: The Chinese House from Courtyard to City
description: Offered in Beijing, China. The Chinese house as the fundamental module of pre-1949 Chinese architecture and urbanism. Introduction to the programmatic, situational, and tectonic range of the courtyard house type. The elasticity and persistence of this type explored in three radically different sites: a central Beijing hutong siheyuan, an Anhui village, and the Forbidden City. Travel to sites in China, using surveying, analysis, and design exercises to gain an understanding of each location. Joint studio with Tsinghua University's School of Architecture. Must be taken in conjunction with ARCH S241. Prerequisite: an introductory course in architecture or drawing. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from China, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 1. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,900. Course Dates: May 14 - July 2.

subject: ARCH
title: Chinese LandscapeArch&Urbanism
description: Offered in Beijing, China. Themes in the history and theory of the Chinese built environment explored in relation to the typology of the Chinese house. Introduction to the history, culture, and evolution of Chinese architecture, gardens, and urbanism. The specific context of each project site examined through close readings and invited lectures. Must be taken in conjunction with ARCH S240. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from China, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 1. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,900. Course Dates: May 14 - July 2.

subject: ARCH
title: Modern Architecture
description: Key developments in modernist architecture and urbanism from 1900 to the present, including art nouveau, constructivism, futurism, monumentalism and utopianism after World War II, and the present clash between new urbanism and neo-avant-gardism. Modernist architecture as an aesthetic response to historical events and forces that shape modern society and the human environment. Includes field trips to view extraordinary examples of modern architecture in New Haven. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ART
title: Digital Photography

subject: ART
title: Critical Theory/Video

subject: ART
title: Advanced Drawing/Printmaking

subject: ART
title: Advanced Painting/3-D Studio

subject: ART
title: Basic Drawing
description: An introduction to drawing, emphasizing pictorial syntax and the articulation of space. Class work is based on observational study. Assigned projects address fundamental technical and conceptual problems suggested by historical and recent artistic practice. No prior drawing experience necessary. Enrollment limited to 20 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,200. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ART
title: Introductory Sculpture: Wood
description: The focus of this course is on understanding wood technology and using machines and hand tools in the context of the studio. Students will be introduced to the range of what sculpture might be. Assignments are designed to foster hands-on appreciation of materials and craftsmanship, as well as initiate awareness of the aesthetic and political implications of handmade objects in a digital world. Attention is paid throughout the course to understanding and articulating form in space, and to helping students develop personal ways of working alongside, and in response to, current issues in contemporary sculpture. Group discussions and presentations complement the studio work. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,200. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ART
title: Painting Basics
description: An introduction to basic painting issues, stressing a beginning command of the conventions of pictorial space and the language of color. Class assignments and individual projects explore technical, conceptual, and historical issues central to the language of painting. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,200. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ART
title: Introduction to Graphic Design
long_title: Introduction to Graphic Design: Typography for Print and Video
description: A studio introduction to graphic design with emphasis on typography. In addition to typography, topics will include color, visual hierarchy, word/image relationships, and type in motion. Development of a verbal and visual vocabulary to discuss and critique typographic design for print and video or other screen-based work. Programs such as InDesign, Adobe Afteraffects, and Adobe Photoshop may be used for some projects in the computer facilities at the Yale School of Art. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,200. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ART
title: Intro to Digital Photography
description: Exploration of the transition of photographic processes and techniques into digital formats. A range of tools are presented including scanning, digital cameras, retouching, color correction, basic composition, and inkjet printing. Students produce original work throughout the technical component of the class. After mastering the basics, students work toward the completion of a final project, and the focus of the remaining classes is on critiques. Throughout the term, lectures and presentations raise critical issues concerning the impact of digital applications and by-products on the medium of photography. Students must have access to a digital camera and bring it to class. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,200. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ART
title: Introduction to Digital Video
description: Digital video represents a provocative combination of vernacular and classical styles through its ease of use and its potential for extremely high production values. This class introduces the basic tools of digital video production. Topics include DV camera operation, sound, and Mac-based editing. After students learn these basic techniques, the remainder of the class consists of individual and collaborative assignments that explore the visual language and production challenges of DV. This class is directed to the spatial and visual aspects of the medium rather than the narrative. The class also includes screenings of experimental films, video art, and DV feature films.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,200. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ART
title: Intro Interactive Design: WWW
long_title: Introduction to Interactive Design: World Wide Web
description: A studio introduction to typographic communication on the internet. Students will conceive, design, and build a website with a content management system. The relationship between web server, web browser, content author, graphic designer, and user will be emphasized as both technical issues and aesthetic opportunities. Sustainability and evolution of a website over time is emphasized. HTML, CSS, image preparation, and basics of PHP will be taught utilizing the computer facilities at the Yale School of Art. No previous knowledge necessary. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,200. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ASTR
title: Planets and Stars
description: For non-science majors. An introduction to stars and planetary systems. Topics include the solar system and extrasolar planets, planet and star formation, and the evolution of stars from birth to death. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of elementary algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ASTR
title: Galaxies and the Universe
description: A nontechnical introduction to stellar populations and the structure and evolution of the Milky Way galaxy; external galaxies, radio galaxies, and quasars; cosmology and the expanding universe. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of elementary algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ASTR
title: IntoObservationalAstrophysics
description: Offered in Santiago, Chile. Introduction to astrophysics and to ground-based observing techniques. Extensive observing using research facilities at the Cerro Calan and Cerro Tololo Observatories. Field trips to other major Andean observatories. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Santiago, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: Physics 180 or equivalent. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Course Dates: May 28 - July 9.

subject: BIS
title: Accelerated Biostats
description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the use of statistics in the fields of epidemiology, public health, and clinical research. Students gain experience conducting and interpreting a broad range of statistical analyses. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability distributions, parameter estimation, hypothesis testing, sampling, analysis of variance, nonparametric tests, and linear regression. Through weekly computer laboratory sessions, students become familiar with the SAS statistical software package. Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.

subject: BRST
title: ModernistLondon:Lit & the Arts

subject: BRST
title: LondonTheatre:ContemporayScene

subject: BRST
title: W. Hogarth's LondonArtist&City

subject: BRST
title: W.MorrisThry&Practice of Craft

subject: CDE
title: Advanced SBS
long_title: Accelerated Social and Behavioral Influences on Health
description: This course provides students with an introduction to social and behavioral science issues that influence patterns of health and health care delivery. The focus is on the integration of biomedical, social, psychological, and behavioral factors that must be taken into consideration when public health initiatives are developed and implemented. This course emphasizes the integration of research from the social and behavioral sciences with epidemiology and biomedical sciences. Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.

subject: CDE
title: Accelerated Epidemiology
description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to epidemiologic concepts and methods. Topics include measurement of disease occurrence, descriptive epidemiology, randomized controlled trials, cohort studies, case-control studies, cross-sectional studies, ecologic studies, screening principles, reliability and validity, bias, confounding, and effect modification. After completing this course, students are able to calculate and interpret epidemiologic parameters, identify the strengths and weaknesses of various study designs, and apply the principles and methods of epidemiology to the design and analysis of new studies. Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.

subject: CGSC
title: Introduction Cognitive Science
description: Multidisciplinary approach to studying the nature of the mind. How the fields of philosophy, psychology, neuroscience, computer science, and linguistics contribute methods, theories, and research to addressing questions about how the mind works. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: CHEM
title: ComprehensiveGeneralChemistry
description: A comprehensive survey of modern descriptive inorganic and physical chemistry, intended for students with high school preparation in chemistry. Stoichiometry, atomic structure, chemical bonding, molecular structure, gas laws, properties of solutions. These courses (CHEM S114/S115), with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Pre-college students are advised to take CHEM S114 during Session B. Students may enroll in Session A, May 30 - July 1, Meets M-F 10:30-11:45, Instructor John Cramer (CRN 30056) with optional discussion section MWTH 9:30-10:20; or Session B, July 4 - August 5, Meets M-F 9:15-10:30, Instructor Narasimhan Ganapathi (CRN 30057). 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000.

subject: CHEM
title: ComprehensiveGeneralChemistry
description: A comprehensive survey of modern descriptive inorganic and physical chemistry, intended for students with high school preparation in chemistry. Stoichiometry, atomic structure, chemical bonding, molecular structure, gas laws, properties of solutions. These courses (CHEM S114/S115), with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Pre-college students are advised to take CHEM S114 during Session B. Students may enroll in Session A, May 30 - July 1, Meets M-F 10:30-11:45, Instructor John Cramer (CRN 30056) with optional discussion section MWTH 9:30-10:20; or Session B, July 4 - August 5, Meets M-F 9:15-10:30, Instructor Narasimhan Ganapathi (CRN 30057). 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000.

subject: CHEM
title: ComprehensiveGeneralChemistry
description: A comprehensive survey of modern descriptive inorganic and physical chemistry, intended for students with high school preparation in chemistry. Session B: chemical kinetics and thermodynamics, chemical equilibria, acid-base theory, electrochemistry, transition metal chemistry, introduction to organic chemistry. These courses (CHEM S114/S115), with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Pre-college students should take CHEM S114 during Session B. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: CHEM
title: General Chemistry Lab
description: Laboratory techniques required for qualitative and quantitative analysis, synthesis of inorganic compounds, and simple thermodynamic measurements. May be taken concurrently with CHEM S114 or subsequently. For college students only. 1/2 Credit. Tuition: $1,500. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: CHEM
title: General Chemistry Lab
description: Laboratory techniques required for qualitative and quantitative analysis, synthesis of inorganic compounds, and simple thermodynamic measurements. May be taken concurrently with CHEM S115 or subsequently. For college students only. 1/2 Credit. Tuition: $1,500. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: CHEM
title: Organic Chemistry
description: The fundamental principles of organic chemistry. Session A: structure and bonding, chemical energetics, stereochemistry, alkanes, nucleophilic substitution, infrared and NMR spectroscopy, alkenes and alkynes, alcohols and ethers. These courses (CHEM S220/S221), with laboratories, satisfy departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. For college students only. After college level general chemistry. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: CHEM
title: Organic Chemistry
description: The fundamental principles of organic chemistry. Session B: aldehydes and ketones, strategies in organic synthesis, carboxylic acid derivatives, carbonyl condensation reactions, sulfur and phosphorus compounds, bifunctional molecules, carbohydrates, organic nitrogen compounds, amino acids and proteins. These courses (CHEM S220/S221), with laboratories, satisfy departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. For college students only. After college level general chemistry. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: CHEM
title: Lab for Organic Chemistry
description: Introductory laboratory course covering basic synthetic and analytic techniques in organic chemistry. May be taken concurrently with CHEM S-220 or subsequently. For college students only. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses (CHEM S-222/S-223) must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1/2 Credit. Tuition: $1,500. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: CHEM
title: Lab for Organic Chemistry
description: Introductory laboratory course covering basic synthetic and analytic techniques in organic chemistry. May be taken concurrently with CHEM S-221 or subsequently. For college students only. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses (CHEM S-222/S-223)must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1/2 Credit. Tuition: $1,500. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: CLCV
title: Classical Mythologies
description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: CPSC
title: Great Ideas Computer Science
description: An introduction for nonmajors to some of the most important ideas in computer science: what the computer is; how it works; what it can do and what it cannot do, now and in the future. Topics include algorithms, elementary programming, hardware, language interpretation, software engineering, complexity, models of computation, and artificial intelligence. No previous programming experience required. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: CPSC
title: Issues Internet&Telecomms Law
long_title: Issues in Internet and Telecommunications Law
description: An exploration of the myriad ways in which law and technology intersect, with a special focus on telecommunications. Topics include the Bell system monopoly, national broadband, Net neutrality, voice-over-Internet protocol, cable television, and mobile networks. No previous experience with computers or law necessary. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: CZEC
title: Prague Film and Fiction
long_title: Kafka's Spirit: Prague Film and Fiction
description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, and language. Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on Main Street), Jan Svêrák (Kolja), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Václav Havel, Ivan Klíma, and Arnost Lustig. Includes a comprehensive introduction to basic Czech for students with little or no knowledge of the language. The Czech language component is an integral cultural part of the course; all students must attend and participate in both morning and afternoon sessions. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information, e-mail summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session B: July 2 - August 6.

subject: DRAM
title: DrawRenderingFigureWatercolor

subject: DRAM
title: IntroDraftingforScenicDesign

subject: DRAM
title: Photoshop and Digital Media

subject: DRAM
title: Catalysts for Social Progress

subject: E&EB
title: Princ of Evol, Ecol, & Beh
long_title: Principles of Evolution, Ecology and Behavior
description: The principles of evolution, ecology, and behavior explained and illustrated by recent advances that have changed the field. Emphasis on important events in the history and key transitions in the organization of life. This course, with laboratory, meets departmental requirements for the major, and is appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Students are encouraged to take this course with the laboratory, E&EB S123, which together constitute a full course load. Students may enroll in Session A, May 30 - July 1, Meets M-F 9-10:30, Instructor Paul Whitehead (CRN 30080) or Session B, July 4 - August 5, Meets M-F 10:30-11:45, Instructor Gail Hartnett (CRN 30078). Pre-college students should take this course during Session B and must also take E&EB S123 concurrently. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000.

subject: E&EB
title: Princ of Evol, Ecol, & Beh
long_title: Principles of Evolution, Ecology and Behavior
description: The principles of evolution, ecology, and behavior explained and illustrated by recent advances that have changed the field. Emphasis on important events in the history and key transitions in the organization of life. This course, with laboratory, meets departmental requirements for the major, and is appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Students are encouraged to take this course with the laboratory, E&EB S123, which together constitute a full course load. Students may enroll in Session A, May 30 - July 1, Meets M-F 9-10:30, Instructor Paul Whitehead (CRN 30080) or Session B, July 4 - August 5, Meets M-F 10:30-11:45, Instructor Gail Hartnett (CRN 30078). Pre-college students should take this course during Session B and must also take E&EB S123 concurrently. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000.

subject: E&EB
title: Lab Prin of Evol, Ecol & Beh
long_title: Laboratory for Principles of Evolution, Ecology and Behavior
description: Experimental approaches to organismal and population biology, including study of the diversity of life. Students may enroll in Session A, May 30 - July 1, Meets TTh 1-4 (CRN 30081) or Session B, July 4 - August 5, Meets MW 1-4 (CRN 30082). Concurrently with or after E&EB S122. ½ Credit. Tuition $1,500.

subject: ECON
title: Introductory Microeconomics
description: Introduction to the principles of microeconomics, supply and demand, consumer theory, and competitive markets. Applications to contemporary policy issues such as rent control, minimum wage, antitrust policy, pollution, and income inequality. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. CRN 30289 Session A: May 30 - July 1. CRN 30083 Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ECON
title: Introductory Microeconomics
description: Introduction to the principles of microeconomics, supply and demand, consumer theory, and competitive markets. Applications to contemporary policy issues such as rent control, minimum wage, antitrust policy, pollution, and income inequality. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. CRN 30289 Session A: May 30 - July 1. CRN 30083 Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ECON
title: Introductory Macroeconomics
description: Theories of income determination, economic growth, and international trade applied to problems of fiscal and monetary policy of developed countries and to economic problems facing developing countries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4-August 5.

subject: ECON
title: Computational Finance
description: This is an advanced undergraduate course in asset pricing. The binomial pricing model allows us to introduce in a discrete time setting all of the fundamental concepts used in the continuous time-theory of asset valuation and hedging of risk-- including martingales, risk-neutral pricing and the stochastic calculus -- that are the basis for the Black-Scholes option pricing formula. Prerequisite: MATH 118 and ECON S131 or equivalents. 1 credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ECON
title: Computational Finance
description: Offered online. This is an advanced undergraduate course in asset pricing. The binomial pricing model allows us to introduce in a discrete time setting all of the fundamental concepts used in the continuous time-theory of asset valuation and hedging of risk-- including martingales, risk-neutral pricing and the stochastic calculus -- that are the basis for the Black-Scholes option pricing formula. Prerequisite: MATH 118 and ECON S121 or equivalents. 1 credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ECON
title: CANCELLED
description: This is an introduction to financial time series. As such we discuss stationary time series,i.e., ARMA processes and nonstationary time series,i.e., ARIMA processes. The material on financial time series will cover the ARCH and GARCH models of heteroscedasticity. Prerequisites: MATH 120, ECON 121 and ECON 131 or equivalents. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ECON
title: The Economics of Corruption
description: Corruption, a manifestation of the principal-agent problem, is an obstacle to economic efficiency.  This course examines the economic, cultural, and political causes and consequences of corruption; cross-country comparisons of corruption levels; and examples of successful reforms and policies to combat corruption in bureaucracy and business. Prerequisite: ECON 115a or b, Introduction to Microeconomics, or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ECON
title: Topics in Intn'l Economics
description: This course is full and is not accepting anymore applications for summer 2011. This course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities' Global Summer Program. For IARU/GSP students only. Yale students may apply for a limited number of spaces. Full tuition scholarships available. Recent developments in international economics. Trade policy and market structure; the economics of trading blocs such as the EEC and NAFTA; the economic consequences of continued U.S. external deficits; globalization and inequality; exchange rates, interest rates, and volatility; speculative capital flows and exchange rate policies; and financial crises and the prospects for the European Monetary Union. Prerequisites: intermediate microeconomics and macroeconomics or equivalents. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: EENG
title: The Digital Information Age
description: An introduction to electrical engineering  with applications to information transmission and coding in smart phones.  Basic electrical components, sensors, and actuators; time waveforms and frequency spectra;   analog to digital conversion; Digital logic circuits; codes for error correction, compression and encryption; and communication over the Internet. Excel exercises for graphical analysis and display design. Intended for students in the humanities and social sciences and for freshmen considering a major in electrical engineering. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ENAS
title: Science of Modern Technology
description: Seminar that examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ENAS
title: Data Analysis and Forecasting
description: Quantitative reasoning applied to interpretation of actual data. Concepts illustrated with models that fit linear and non-linear trends to data using random search techniques. Statistical measures predict accuracy of forecasts. Analysis and data processing performed with Excel spreadsheets using macros and elementary Visual Basic. Case studies include funds depletion, forecasting life expectancy and prediction of Olympic gold medal performance. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ENAS
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ENGL
title: Writing Seminars I
description: An introduction to argument and analysis, using a broad spectrum of modern nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ENGL
title: Writing Seminars I
description: An introduction to argument and analysis, using a broad spectrum of modern nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ENGL
title: Writing About Literature I
description: An exploration of the relationship between science and art through the primary example of literature. Special emphasis on learning to write analytical arguments about narrative prose fiction, poetry, drama, and nonfiction prose. Writers include William Shakespeare, Margaret Cavendish, Charles Darwin, Emily Dickinson, Herculine Barbin, Bertolt Brecht, and Essex Hemphill. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ENGL
title: Writing Seminars II
description: In this course we will read essays by the luminaries of the food world, and we will view popular food films. Assignments will focus on family meals, recipes, and cookbooks. We will blog about ice cream, hotdogs, and other discoveries about eating well summer foods. Prerequisite: ENGL 114 or equivalent. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ENGL
title: Intro Study Am Literature
long_title: Introduction to the Study of American Literature
description: This course serves as both an introduction to as well as an exploration of American literature from the nineteenth century to the present.  We will ask many questions of these texts, not the least of which is "what do we mean when we say 'American'"  Given the wide range of the body of work that comprises American literature, however, we will also periodically ask in passing what we mean by "literature," so as to consider what roles the literary plays in creating and shaping the possibilities of social imagination, private and public discourse, as well as one's own identity. Emphasis on analytical reading, critical writing, and class discussions. Authors include Melville, Poe, Hawthorne, Whitman, Dickinson, Barnes, Toomer, H. Crane, W. C. Williams, L. Hughes, and M. Robinson. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ENGL
title: The Art of Poetry
description: A writing workshop that focuses on the foundations and intricate dynamics of poetry as a writer's continuing and intimate process. Close attention to authentic voice, urgency and energy, fresh and unpredictable language, arresting imagery and figures of speech, and imaginative leaps. Poems from around the world serve as points of departure for discussions of craft and free, artistic expression. Students write and revise one original work of poetry for each class. Counts toward the requirements for the major in English, but does not count toward the writing concentration. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be emailed to summer.session@yale.edu separately. Application deadline: May 1. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $,3000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ENGL
title: Narrative Writing
description: A course that combines both fiction and nonfiction writing, conducted as a workshop. The focus will be on elements common to all storytelling - among them, narrative development, voice, and clarity of language and thought. Students will have the opportunity to write short fiction, memoir, and journalistic nonfiction. They may concentrate in one genre, or, if they wish, experiment with genres new to them. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be emailed to summer.session@yale.edu separately. Application deadline: May 1. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ENGL
title: ShakespeareHistories&Tragedies
description: Study of three histories and seven tragedies at the pinnacle of Shakespeare's career. Focus on the source of each play's pathos and the nature of its poetic sublimity; some attention to performance and to the relation between the genres of history and tragedy. Extensive practice in writing short and medium-sized critical essays. Students should come to the first class having read Julius Caesar.   (The Signet edition,  ordered through Labyrinth Books, is preferred, but the  Norton genre volumes are especially handsome  substitutions; the Arden single play editions are more than acceptable if their price is not intimidating.)  The regular course meetings will be supplemented by six  one-hour evening screenings, and students are required to attend at least three of these. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4- August 5.

subject: ENGL
title: James Joyce's "Ulysses"
description: An in-depth reading of James Joyce's twentieth-century epic Ulysses, one of the primary texts of literary modernism. Close analysis of Joyce's prose, including examination of its devices and charting of the correspondences and cross-references so important to an understanding of the novel. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ENGL
title: CANCELLED
description: A study of the major poetic works of John Milton, and of the influence of Milton's poetry on the prose fiction of later generations. Readings include Milton's Comus, Lycidas, Paradise Lost, Paradise Regained, and Samson Agonistes, as well as works by later readers of Milton such as Dostoevsky, Nathanael West, and Philip Pullman.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ENGL
title: Cultural History of Publishing
long_title: From Gutenberg to Google Books: The Cultural History of Publishing, 1450 to the Present
description: The social, cultural, and technological aspects of book publishing, production, and distribution from the fifteenth century to the present. Emphasis on three critical eras and technologies: the Renaissance and the mechanically reproduced book, the nineteenth century and the rise of mass literacy and mass distribution, and the current digital age, when long-held assumptions about books, publishing, and reading will be examined and far-reaching questions about literacy, distribution, global access and equity, and even cognitive science discussed. The course is taught as a seminar at the Beinecke Rare Book Library through a series of first-hand encounters with rare manuscripts, books, prints, and other primary sources, from the medieval period through the present day. In addition, several class meetings will take place in other Yale collections that contain objects related to our study of the book as an instrument and agent of social change.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ENGL
title: Love Poetry
description: A survey of love poetry in the anglophone tradition.  From Sappho to Shakespeare, Byron to Bishop, verse has been an enduring -- though changing -- vehicle for expressing the emotions of romantic love. http://engls24501sum11.commons.yale.edu/. .1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ENGL
title: Modern American Literature
description: A survey of American literature and culture in the first half of the twentieth century. Works by Ernest Hemingway, T.S. Eliot, Ezra Pound, William Carlos Williams, Muriel Rukeyser, Nella Larsen, Langston Hughes, and William Faulkner. Please see online syllabus for readings for the first day of class. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ENGL
title: Modern American Drama
description: In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ENGL
title: The Bible as Literature
description: Study of the Bible as an anthology of works exhibiting a variety of theologies, notions of lieterariness, claims to historicity, and styles. Readings include twenty works selected from both the Hebrew Bible and the New Testament. Students work in two English translations, one of which must be the New Jerusalem Bible. Students should come to the first class having read Genesis 1-11 and should bring a Bible. Yale students who wish to earn pre-1800 credit in the English major may do so by using a King James Bible and completing some supplementary assignments. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ENGL
title: CANCELLED
description: An intensive workshop for dramatic writers of all levels of experience. Playwrights, screenwriters, and performance artists are equally welcome. Readings from dramatic works of many periods, from Sophocles to the Marx Brothers. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be e-mailed to summer.session@yale.edu separately. Application deadline: May 1. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ENGL
title: Investigative Journalism
description: Techniques of in-depth reporting, ranging from interviews and document research to journalistic storytelling; the evolution of "muckraking" in the U.S.; and the ethical, philosophical, and political issues raised by such work. Improvement of the students' practical research and narrative skills through weekly assignments and a term-long writing project. Designed equally for those with journalistic experience and for those with skills in other arenas. Writing sample of a piece of journalism, or an essay of 5 pages revealing research and writing skills is required, and should be emailed to summer.session@yale.edu separately. Application deadline: May 1. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ENGL
title: CANCELLED
description: Exemplary nonfiction portraits and profiles studied as a basis for student compositions of literary portraits of others. Occasional work in other genres such as poetry, the visual arts, and film. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be emailed to summer.session@yale.edu separately. Application deadline: May 1. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ENGL
title: Rev Theater,Film,Dance,Music
long_title: Reviewing Theater, Film, Dance and Music: A Workshop
description: An advanced workshop for writers who want to review the performing arts for newspapers, magazines and other media.  Weekly assignments to review screenings and performances, many of which will be part of New Haven's International Festival of Arts and Ideas.  Class trip to New York City to review a theatre production. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be emailed to summer.session@yale.edu separately. Application deadline: May 1. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ENGL
title: Novel Writing: Chapter One
description: A fiction workshop for writers beginning their first novel. Attention to narrative flow, point of view, voice, setting, dialogue, ways to bring characters to life, and methods of revision. Analysis and critique of student manuscripts. Readings from first chapters of contemporary American novels selected for their technique, emotional power, and resonance. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be emailed to summer.session@yale.edu separately. Application deadline: May 1. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: ENVE
title: Introduction to Green Energy
description: Environmental sustainability and the role of green energy in mitigating the impact of greenhouse gases and global warming. Solar thermal, solar photovoltaic, wind, biofuel, hydro, geothermal, and nuclear power; ocean thermal energy conversion and harvesting of tidal power. System-level performance, overall efficiency, cost, and environmental impact of integrated green energy systems. Laboratory experiments on wind-based electricity generation, solar-powered water electrolyzers for hydrogen production, and hydrogen-powered fuel cells. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: EPH
title: The Internship
description: The Internship is a degree requirement that is completed in the summer between the first and second academic years. Students work with their faculty advisers and the Office of Career Services to identify suitable placements, which include medical care facilities, community agencies, research projects, laboratories, and other sites engaged in public health activities. The internship experience often serves as a basis for the M.P.H. thesis. The internship is displayed on the transcript with a grade of "S" (Satisfactory) upon completion. A course unit is not given for the summer internship. All students must complete a Summer Internship with the exception of those in the Advanced Professional M.P.H. Program. The Summer Internship may be used to complete the Public Health Practice requirement with prior approval from the Office of Community Health.

subject: F&ES
title: F&ES Internship/Research

subject: FILM
title: Prague Film and Fiction
long_title: Kafka's Spirit: Prague Film and Fiction
description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, and language. Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on Main Street), Jan Svêrák (Kolja), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Václav Havel, Ivan Klíma, and Arnost Lustig. Includes a comprehensive introduction to basic Czech for students with little or no knowledge of the language. The Czech language component is an integral cultural part of the course; all students must attend and participate in both morning and afternoon sessions. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information, e-mail summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session B: July 2 - August 6.

subject: FILM
title: Yale Sum Film Institute FAMU
long_title: The Yale Summer Film Institute at FAMU
description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. An intensive, hands-on exploration of film history, theory and practice, offered in partnership with FAMU, the national film academy of the Czech Republic. At the core of the workshop is a sequence of exercises and projects that recapitulates the evolution of film language, from its silent beginnings through its classical period to its post-modern present. Each exercise and project, guided by instructors from FAMU and Yale, and supported by topical lectures, screenings and workshops, will advance the student's understanding of film as art, craft and cultural institution. Cultural trips and activities include: a one-day orientation program comprising a welcome lunch, a walking tour of Prague, and an inaugural dinner; a 10-day introductory language course; a weekend trip to Uherské Hradiste for the opening weekend of the 37th annual Summer Film School, a unique film festival known throughout Europe for its energy and dynamism; and a celebratory farewell dinner. In the final week of the workshop, the student will draw on this understanding to produce a comprehensive final project. All instruction will be in English. Some previous film study is recommended, but not required. Enrollment limited to 16. Application deadline: February 1. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Yale Credit: Tuition: $3,000. 1 FAMU Credit: Tuition $3,000. Tuition is $6,000 total. Session B: July 2 - August 6.

subject: FILM
title: Paris and the Cinema
description: Offered in Paris, France. Introduction to French film history and culture focusing on the representation of Paris in film, photography and literature, with an emphasis on Paris as cultural capital of the cinema. Readings include essays on French film and culture, as well as novels and graphic novels by Aragon and Malet-Tardi. Visits to film locations and museums such as Le Forum Des Images, Le Centre Pompidou and La Cinematheque Francaise. Films include Les Vampires, Breathless, Les Amants de Pont-Neuf, La Haine, and Amelie. All readings and films in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 2 - August 6.

subject: FILM
title: Hollywd Novel & Hollywd Movie
long_title: The Hollywood Novel and the Hollywood Movie
description: A survey of the histories of both the Hollywood novel and films about Hollywood. Examination of the ways in which these two genres portray "the dream factory" - its past, its present, and its future - as well as the way they interact. Books include Harry Leon Wilson's Merton at the Movies, Horace McCoy's They Shoot Horses, Don't They? and I Should Have Stayed Home, F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Last Tycoon, Budd Schulberg's What Makes Sammy Run, and Gore Vidal's Myra Breckenridge. Films include What Price Hollywood? A Star Is Born, Sunset Boulevard, In a Lonely Place, The Star, and The Player. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: FILM
title: CANCELLED
description: Offered in Tokyo, Japan. Exploration of animation (anime) and graphic novels (manga) in contemporary Japan. Special attention to the social and historical contexts of the production and consumption of manga and anime and to themes of gender and sexuality found within. Includes visits to animation and manga studios and museums, fan conventions, the Cosplay scene, and Kyoto. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session B: July 2 - August 6.

subject: FILM
title: Intensive Filmmaking Workshop
description: An intensive, comprehensive hands-on workshop in which the problems and aesthetics of filmmaking are studied in practice as well as theory. Students learn the narrative film form and its collaborative nature by participating in the production process. By screening classic narrative masterpieces they will gain a sense of the medium's historical and aesthetic as well as develop a common vocabulary and point of reference with their fellow collaborators. The students will begin with seminars, readings and exercises that cover working with actors, script analysis, producing, camera, lighting, sound and editing and then move on to an actual production where as a group they make a short HD movie. Film professionals from various areas of expertise instruct and guide students in the application of industry standards to the exercises projects. The course is fully integrated with FILM S203 to provide filmmakers with a pool of acting talent and enable students to move beyond the technological requirements of the medium. This workshop requires a full daily commitment of the student's time, including 5 hours of classroom instruction, 2 hours of screenings, 1-2 hours of reading homework and workshop projects outside of class time and on weekends.  Enrollment limited to 16. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,800. More information on course web page: http://www.yale.edu/summer/progrms/film/filmmaking.html. . Course dates: June 13 - July 22.

subject: FILM
title: Acting in Film
description: An intensive, full-time, hands-on workshop that is fully integrated with the Intensive Filmmaking Workshop (Film S-202) which allows the student actor to solve the artistic problems and technical challenges of film acting. Students begin with exercises that acclimate them to the tenets of good acting under the pressures and demands of the filmic medium. Then, with rehearsed scene work, they learn the technical language of cinema and they participate in various filmmaking practices. Their knowledge and techniques are tested by acting in one or more of the films produced by the Intensive Filmmaking Workshop. With the Filmmaking Workshop, the students screen classic narrative masterpieces nightly in order to gain a sense of the medium's historical and aesthetic context as well as to develop a common vocabulary and point of reference with fellow collaborators. Screenings, readings, and rehearsals supplement practical application. Daily commitments include, but are not limited to: 3-5 hours daily of classroom instruction, 2.5 hours of nightly screenings, 1-3 hours daily reading, rehearsal and shooting sessions outside of classroom time and on weekends. Enrollment limited to 16. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. More information on course web page: http://www.yale.edu/summer/progrms/film/acting.html. Dates: June 13 - July 22, M-Th  9.30-12.30; M, W 2-4; Screenings M-Th 7-10 P.M.

subject: FILM
title: The Business of Hollywood
long_title: Money and Media: the Business of Hollywood
description: An examination of the key events and ideas that shape the modern motion picture business from financial, institutional, and historical standpoints. Topics include ways that the business has evolved in response to changes in technology, distribution, and competition; how the business dictates what ends up on screen; and relationships among studios, actors, agents, independent filmmakers, distributors, and the viewing audience. Industry practitioners discuss special topics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 5 - August 6.

subject: FILM
title: CANCELLED
description: Shakespeare's plays examined in and through film. Ways in which the processes of film adaptation and production have reshaped the form and meaning of Shakespeare's works. Emphasis on the specifics of cinematic form and style in relation to the theatrical conditions for which the plays were originally written. Analysis of films from different historical periods, cultural contexts, and genres. Some discussion of relevant historical and theoretical developments. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: FILM
title: Film, Video & American History
description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment.  This course seeks to expand its students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture and society.  In-class screenings will include The Birth of a Nation, Scarface, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Apocalypse Now, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: FILM
title: Screenwriting
description: A seminar and workshop in screenplay writing. Students learn the basics of the craft by reading existing scripts, looking at films from a writer's perspective, and writing a short screenplay. Additional hours of individual screenings required. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: FILM
title: Outlaw Cinema
description: The outlaw as a romanticized, mythic figure in Anglo-American film and culture. Analysis of movies and screenplays whose characters refuse to conform to a restrictive social order in which they have a marginal place. Evolving depictions of the outlaw in mainstream cinema after World War II.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 5 - August 6.

subject: FILM
title: Television and Crime
description: Examines crime drama (with a concentration on HBO's "THE WIRE"), crime news, reality TV, and crime documentaries. Analysis of how depictions in these media effect law enforcement, government, politics, labor, community, education, criminality/violence, progressive and conservative pundits, judicial responsibility and social perceptions of race, class, gender, and sexuality. 60 Minutes correspondent Leslie Stahl, a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, will visit and discuss the history of sexism in broadcasting; her interviews with Mark Zuckerberg & Supreme Court Justice Scalia; her investigations into social media crime; and the controversy surrounding familial searches of DNA databases. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: FILM
title: Television Situation Comedy
description: An introductory analysis of the television situation comedy in America from its beginnings in the 1950s to the present time. Exploration of how this popular and powerful genre grew and changed, how it influenced America, and how it was influenced by America in its depictions of family life, race and ethnicity, stereotypes, fantasy, feminism, war, progressive forms of cultural and racial inclusion, and contemporary looks at single life and gay liberation. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: FREN
title: Elem & Intermediate French
description: Intensive training and practice in all the language skills through extensive use of audio and video material, with an initial emphasis on listening and speaking. Authentic, unsimplified French is used as in actual situations. Emphasis on communicative proficiency, the development of skills, self-expression, and cultural insights. Classes are supplemented by regular laboratory assignments. Conducted entirely in French. Daily classroom and laboratory attendance is required. For students with no previous study of French. 1 1/2 credits. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S120 in the same summer for credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: FREN
title: Elem & Intermediate French
description: Continuation of FREN S110. 1 1/2 Credits. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S110 in the same summer for credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: FREN
title: Intermediate&Advanced French I
description: Part 1 of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Conducted entirely in French. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S140. Prerequisite: FREN 120, 121 or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: June 6 - July 30.

subject: FREN
title: Intermediate&Advanced FrenchII
description: Offered in Paris, France. Part 2 of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Conducted entirely in French. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S130. Prerequisite: FREN 120, 121 or equivalent.  Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,000. Course dates: June 6 - July 30.

subject: FREN
title: Advanced Language Practice II
description: Offered in Paris, France. An advanced language course intended to improve students' comprehension of spoken and written French as well as their speaking and writing skills. Museum visits, theater outings, and weekend trips complement the reading of modern fiction and nonfiction texts. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: after FREN 140, 145, or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 28 - July 2.

subject: FREN
title: Advanced Culture&Conversation
description: Offered in Paris, France. Intensive oral practice for advanced students. An introduction to contemporary French culture and current events while sharing day-to-day life with Parisians. In small groups, students conduct surveys and interviews, melding the techniques of ethnography and photojournalism. Classroom activities include students' presentation of their findings; discussions and debates based on readings of newspapers and other periodicals; films; songs; stories; and clips from French television. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: after FREN 150, 151, or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 28 - July 2.

subject: FREN
title: Age of Cathedrals
description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. Study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France. Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual life in twelfth- and thirteenth-century Paris. Discussion of historical and literary works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, and Thibaut de Champagne. Visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens and Cluny Museum. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session B: July 2 - August 6.

subject: FREN
title: Belle Epoque France
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in France between the Franco-Prussian War and World War I. Includes visits to museums, monuments, art nouveau cafés, bistrots, brasseries, and other sites in Paris. Readings, writing, and discussion in French. Prerequisite: two courses in the FREN 150-159 range or the equivalent. Recommended preparation: a course in the FREN 170-175 range. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session A: May 28 - July 2.

subject: FREN
title: French Lit & Arts after 1945
description: Offered in Paris, France. An introduction to French literature and arts after World War II.
