Topics include existentialism, intellectual and artistic life of Paris in the 1950s, the theater of the absurd, cinema d'auteur, and the contemporary French novel. Exploration of Parisian cultural life through visits to literary cafes, the National Library, the Cinematheque, theaters, and bookstores. Readings, writing, and discussion in French. Prerequisite: two courses in the FREN 150-159 range or the equivalent. Recommended preparation: a course in the FREN 170-175 range. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 2 - August 6

subject: GMAN
title: Intermediate German I
description: Part 1 of an intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Application deadline: February 1 . Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S140. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: GMAN
title: Intermediate German II
description: Offered in Berlin, Germany. Part 2 of an intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S130. Prerequisite: GMAN 130 or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: GMAN
title: Metropolis Berlin
description: Offered in Berlin, Germany. An advanced language course focused on improving upper-level language skills through exploration of the culture, politics, art, and history of twentieth-century Berlin. Dicussion of current events; site visits in Berlin; interviews with host families. Topics include history and memory, art and music, architecture and living conditions, youth and alternative cultures, and national and international politics. Prerequisite: GMAN 140a or b or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, room and board costs in Germany , and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Course dates: June 25-July 30. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000.

subject: GREK
title: Beg Greek: Elements of Grammar
long_title: Beginning Greek: The Elements of Grammar
description: Introduction to ancient Greek. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for GREK S120. No prior knowledge of Greek assumed. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: GREK
title: Beg Greek:Review of Grammar
long_title: Beginning Greek: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
description: Continuation of GREK S110.  Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Greek authors. The sequence GREK S110, S120 prepares for GREK 131 or 141.  Prerequisite: GREK S110 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: HIST
title: Religion, War, and America
description: The relationship between religion and war in American history from colonial beginnings through Vietnam. The religious meaning of America, including the religious meanings of Americans at war; the mutually reinforcing influences of nationalism and religion; war as the norm of American national life; the concept of civil religion; biblical and messianic contexts of key U.S. conflicts. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: HIST
title: History of American West
long_title: The History of the American West
description: The history of westward expansion and of the places west of the Mississippi River, as told through the people who saw it, experienced it, and made it happen.  Beginning in the colonial era and concluding in the present day, with an emphasis on the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.  Research will include the use of Overland Diaries from the Beinecke.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: HIST
title: Film, Video & American History
description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment.  This course seeks to expand its students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture and society.  In-class screenings will include The Birth of a Nation, Scarface, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Apocalypse Now, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: HIST
title: Cultural History of Publishing
long_title: From Gutenberg to Google Books: The Cultural History of Publishing, 1450 to the Present
description: The social, cultural, and technological aspects of book publishing, production, and distribution from the fifteenth century to the present. Emphasis on three critical eras and technologies: the Renaissance and the mechanically reproduced book, the nineteenth century and the rise of mass literacy and mass distribution, and the current digital age, when long-held assumptions about books, publishing, and reading will be examined and far-reaching questions about literacy, distribution, global access and equity, and even cognitive science discussed. The course is taught as a seminar at the Beinecke Rare Book Library through a series of first-hand encounters with rare manuscripts, books, prints, and other primary sources, from the medieval period through the present day. In addition, several class meetings will take place in other Yale collections that contain objects related to our study of the book as an instrument and agent of social change.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: HIST
title: Russia and the West
description: Explores encounters between Russia and the West from the eighteenth century to the present.  How has Russia reacted to major events and ideas in the West, and vice-versa?  Examines selected major political events and intellectual controversies, as well cross-cultural exchange. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: HIST
title: The Cold War
description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4-August 5.

subject: HIST
title: History of Southeastern Europe
long_title: History and Culture of Southeastern Europe
description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study of southeastern Europe from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and postcommunist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with SOCY S286. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,900. Session B: July 2 - August 6.

subject: HIST
title: Empires of East Asia
description: Survey of the history of China, Japan, and Korea from the seventh century to the present. Focus on three separate empires: the Tang, Manchu, and Japanese. Attention to interactions among East Asian regions in the past and today. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: HIST
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Iran, Iraq, and the Persian Gulf
description: Major conflicts, revolutions, and wars in the Persian Gulf during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Topics include conflicts between the Ottoman Empire, Iran, and Arab Gulf areas; Arab-Iranian rivalry; the role of Islam in state and society; tribal communities within states; British occupations; the emergence of Kuwait, Iraq, and modern Iran; revolutions in Iraq and Iran; and the twentieth-century Gulf Wars. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: HIST
title: Central Asia and Empire
description: A survey of the interaction of political, economic, and environmental factors in the history of the Eurasian steppe from antiquity to the modern era, and the interactions of its peoples with civilizations in China, India, Persia, Russia, and Europe. Topics include Scythians, Huns, Mongols, Silk Road trade, expansion of the Russian and Chinese empires into the steppe and the consequent destruction of political structures and economic productivity, Afghanistan as a juncture point, post-Soviet petrostates. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: HIST
title: CANCELLED
description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Survey of the modern history of East Africa, with a focus on health, environment, and society. The rise of Swahili language and culture; slavery and plantation agriculture; colonial regimes, medical discourse, and environmental degradation; agrarian protest and nationalist mobilization; conservation ethics and national parks; female genital cutting; HIV/AIDS. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Mombasa, costs of room and board in Mombasa, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Yale students may petition for one HU area credit. Tuition: $5,800. Course Dates: June 25 - August 6.

subject: HIST
title: World Politics 1917-1919
description: The emergence of internationalism during the final years of World War I and its immediate aftermath, and the descent toward obsolescence of the empire model in world politics. Responses to Woodrow Wilson's peace diplomacy and the League of Nations; the Russian revolution and the subsequent upheaval across Eurasia; the struggles for Indian, Irish, and Czech independence; the birth of modern nationalism in Asia. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: HSAR
title: Intro to HSAR: Prehis to Ren
long_title: Introduction to History of Art: Prehistory to the Renaissance
description: A history of artistic expression from prehistory to the Renaissance. Selected studies of architecture, sculpture, painting, metalwork, manuscript illumination, etc. Lectures in the classroom and gallery talks in the Yale University Art Gallery, Beinecke Library, and The Cloisters Museum in New York. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: HSAR
title: Intro to HSAR: Ren to Modern
long_title: Introduction to History of Art: Renaissance to Modern
description: A survey of Western art from the fifteenth century to the present. Introduction to both the masterpieces of artistic expression and the methods for defining and interpreting those works. Field trips to Yale museums and architectural walking tours complement the study of paintings, sculptures, architecture, and domestic and luxury arts. Readings include survey texts and original sources. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: HSAR
title: CANCELLED
description: Chronological and thematic issues related to the creation, analysis, and collecting of African American art. Introduction to the field of African American art through close engagement with archival sources and art objects held in the Yale University Art Gallery and the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library. Methodologies used to write about art in both African American studies and art history; collecting and museum practices; the relationships between art, artists, and community formations. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: HSAR
title: Art and Science
description: The historical relationship between art and science in the West, from the Renaissance to the present. Case studies illustrate the similarities and differences between the way artists and scientists each model the world, in the studio and the laboratory. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: HSAR
title: Ten Works of Western Art
description: In-depth discussion of ten major works of Western art from the Renaissance to the modern era. Works selected both for their extraordinary qualities and for their capacity to represent a range of periods, places, media, themes, and functions. Includes visits to Yale's art museums to view corollary works of art; some attention to relevant poetry, literature, and film. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: HUMS
title: CANCELLED
description: This course explores the ways in which theater based processes have been used to facilitate learning, promote wellness, and address a variety of social concerns such as access to education and healthcare, poverty, gender-based violence, racism, and displacement. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: HUMS
title: Brains of Genius
long_title: Brains of Genius: Mozart and Friends
description: The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Picasso, and Joyce. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, memory, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: HUMS
title: Brains of Genius
long_title: Brains of Genius: Mozart and Friends
description: This section offered online.The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Picasso, and Joyce. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, memory, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: HUMS
title: Classical Mythologies
description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: HUMS
title: Rome
description: Offered in Rome, Italy. Designed as the complement to HUMS 444, this course will consider how Rome's contributions to western thought are recorded in the very fabric of the city. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rome, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: HUMS 444. Enrollment limited, with preference to Humanities majors and juniors. For further information please contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session A: May 29 - July 2.

subject: HUMS
title: Studio Pract Painting&Drawing
long_title: Studio Practice in Painting and Drawing
description: Offered in Auvillar, France. A program directed towards the liberal arts student and meant to provide a hands-on experience and understanding of the dynamics of the studio strategies for initiating, executing, developing and discussing work. It takes advantage of the special summer period outside of the student's normal responsibility to  focus rigorously on personal issues of idea formulation, creative problem solving and studio research. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Auvillar, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Interview required. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Course dates: June 1 - June 29.

subject: HUMS
title: Age of Cathedrals
description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. Study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France. Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual life in twelfth- and thirteenth-century Paris. Discussion of historical and literary works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, and Thibaut de Champagne. Visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens and Cluny Museum. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session B: July 2 - August 6.

subject: IDRS
title: Ind Res in Sciences - 5A
description: May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a l- or 2-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: IDRS
title: Ind Res in Sciences - 5B
description: May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a l- or 2-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: ITAL
title: Elementary Italian I
description: First part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course. A beginning course with extensive practice in speaking, reading, writing, and listening and a thorough introduction to Italian grammer. Activities include group and pairs work, role-playing, and conversation. Introduction to Italian culture through reading and films. Conducted in Italian. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S120. Credit only on completion of ITAL 120. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: ITAL
title: Elementary Italian ll
description: Offered in Siena, Italy. Second part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course. A continuation of ITAL S110. Conducted in Italian. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S110. Prerequisite: ITAL 110 (Elementary Italian I). Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: ITAL
title: Intermediate Italian
description: First part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. Students complete the equivalent of one term of intermediate Italian during the three weeks on the Yale campus, followed by the equivalent of one term of intermediate Italian during the five weeks in Italy. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL 140. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: ITAL 120 (Elementary Italian II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000.  Course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: ITAL
title: Intermediate Italian
description: First part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. Students complete the equivalent of one term of intermediate Italian during the three weeks on the Yale campus, followed by the equivalent of one term of intermediate Italian during the five weeks in Italy. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL 140. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: ITAL 120 (Elementary Italian II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000.  Course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: ITAL
title: Intermediate Italian II
description: Offered in Siena, Italy. Second part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. Students complete the equivalent of one term of intermediate Italian during the three weeks on the Yale campus, followed by the equivalent of one term of intermediate Italian during the five weeks in Italy. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S130. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: ITAL 130 (Intermediate Italian I) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: ITAL
title: Intermediate Italian II
description: Offered in Siena, Italy. Second part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. Students complete the equivalent of one term of intermediate Italian during the three weeks on the Yale campus, followed by the equivalent of one term of intermediate Italian during the five weeks in Italy. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S130. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: ITAL 130 (Intermediate Italian I) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: ITAL
title: The Three Crowns of Tuscany
description: Offered in Siena, Italy. Close reading of selected texts written by the three cornerstones of Italian literary history: Dante, Petrarch, and Boccaccio. Texts are situated within the specific, concrete topography of Tuscany. The making of Tuscany as a political, moral, and aesthetic myth in the Middle Ages; emergence of the Tuscan language as the standard language of Italy. Readings and discussion in Italian. Prerequisite: ITAL 140b or equivalent. May not be taken for credit after ITAL 334b. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: June 18 - July 23.

subject: LAST
title: Latin American Politics
description: Introduction to historical developments and fundamental political issues in Latin America. Overview of socioeconomic and political development since the discovery of the Americas, with a focus on key contemporary debates. Emphasis on the unique and innovative ways in which Latin American societies approach socioeconomic, political, and cultural conflicts such as military-civilian relationships, internal armed conflict, socioeconomic inequality, and respect for human rights. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: LATN
title: Beg Latin: Elements of Grammar
long_title: Beginning Latin: The Elements of Grammar
description: Introduction to Latin. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for LATN 120.  No prior knowledge of Latin assumed. Primarily for graduate students. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: LATN
title: Beg Latin: Review of Grammar
long_title: Beginning Latin: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
description: Continuation of LATN 110. Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Latin authors. The sequence LATN 110, 120 prepares for 131 or 141. Prerequisite: LATN 110 or equivalent. Primarily for graduate students. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: LATN
title: Medieval Latin
description: Study of medieval Latin's distinctive style and vocabulary. Survey of major historical and literary works of the European Middle Ages. Use of medieval manuscript resources from the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, with an introduction to basics of paleography and codicology. Prerequisites: LATN 141b or equivalents. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: LING
title: A Linguistic History of India
description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Study of the linguistic landscape of India, focusing particularly on the Indo-Aryan and Dravidian linguistic areas. The historical evolution of the multilingual landscape over time, and its political and social implications in contemporary India. Must be taken in conjunction with SAST S305/ANTH S305. Students are responsible for all travels expenses to and from India, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,900. Session A: May 28 - July 2.

subject: LITR
title: Introduction to Narrative
description: Examination of how stories are told in both literary and nonliterary texts, with special attention to the act of decoding and interpreting a narrative. Emphasis on fictional form, the mechanics of plot, and questions of time and character. Topics include confession, memory, language, the representation of the self, the interplay of form and content, and the relationship between fiction and history. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: LITR
title: Classical Mythologies
description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: LITR
title: Age of Cathedrals
description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. Study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France. Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual life in twelfth- and thirteenth-century Paris. Discussion of historical and literary works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, and Thibaut de Champagne. Visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens and Cluny Museum. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session B: July 2 - August 6.

subject: LITR
title: CANCELLED
description: Exploration of various theoretical and practical problems in translation. Topics include the responsibility of the translator to the text, the author and the reader; the reliability of translation as a literary mode; the transmission or perversion of culture via translation; and the specific problems involved with the translation of various genres (poetry, drama, fiction, non-fiction). 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: LITR
title: Paris in the 1920s
description: Offered in Paris, France. The role of Paris in the works of writers such as Joyce, Hemingway, Colette, and Breton. How the situation of the artist as expatriate or exile affects what can be written. Iconoclasts of experimental language who found a congenial home in Paris, including Gertrude Stein and the surrealists. Works of expatriate British and American writers examined in relation to works by contemporary French authors. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 28 - July 2.

subject: MATH
title: CalculusFunctionOneVariable I
long_title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable I
description: Limits, continuity, differentiation of elementary and transcendental functions, applications. No prior acquaintance with calculus is assumed. Pre-college students should enroll in this course only if they have a strong foundation in algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: MATH
title: CalculusFunctionOneVariable I
long_title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable I
description: Limits, continuity, differentiation of elementary and transcendental functions, applications. No prior acquaintance with calculus is assumed. Pre-college students should enroll in this course only if they have a strong foundation in algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: MATH
title: CalculusFunctionOneVariableII
long_title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable II
description: The definite integral, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration, polar coordinates, Taylor series, applications. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: MATH
title: IntroFunctionsSeveralVariables
long_title: Introduction to Functions of Several Variables
description: (Formerly "Mathematics for Economists".) Calculus of functions of several variables, with some linear algebra. Intended for students in the social sciences, especially those majoring in Economics. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). Yale students may not take this course after MATH 120 or 222. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: MATH
title: Calculus-Several Variables
long_title: Calculus of Functions of Several Variables
description: Analytic geometry in three dimensions, using vectors. Real-valued functions of two and three variables, partial derivatives, gradient and directional derivatives, level curves and surfaces, maxima and minima. Parametrized curves in space, motion in space, line integrals; applications. Prerequisite: two terms of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 and 115 or equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: MCDB
title: Principles of MCDB
long_title: Principles of Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology
description: Introduction to biochemistry, genetics, cell biology, and early development. Emphasis on the cell as the basic unit of life; the cell's composition, functions, replication, and differentiation. This course, with laboratory, meets departmental requirements for the major, and is appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Students should take this course with the laboratory, MCDB S121, which together constitute a full course load. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: MCDB
title: Lab for Principles of MCDB
long_title: Laboratory for Principles of Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology
description: Experimental techniques and procedures in molecular and cell biology. Must be taken concurrently with or after MCDB 120. 1/2 Credit. Tuition: $1,500. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: MCDB
title: How The Brain Works
description: For non-science majors. The biology of the brain as it relates to various functions and dysfunctions. Gross anatomy and cellular composition of nervous system tissue; development of the nervous system, including its organization into motor, sensory, and other systems; the biology underlying complex processes such as learning, memory, and mood regulation; psychoactive and performance-enhancing drugs in the brain; disorders such as Alzheimer's disease, autism, and depression. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: MCDB
title: Cell Biology
description: A comprehensive course in cell and molecular biology.  Emphasis on general principles of cell function and rationale and design of pertinent biomedical experiments. Prerequisite: MCDB 120. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: MMES
title: IslamicSocietyCulture&Politics
description: The historical development of the global Muslim community, from its origins in seventh-century Arabia through its spread over subsequent centuries into the Middle East, Africa, Central and South/Southeast Asia, and the West. The tremendous variation and complexity expressed in society, culture, and politics across the Islamic world; Islam as a unifying factor on critical issues such as religious practice, political structure and activism, gender, and cultural expression. 1 Credit. Tuition: $,3000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: MMES
title: Intro to Middle East Politics
description: Offered online. An overview of politics in the Middle East and North Africa. State formation, the roles of religion and oil in politics, political institutions, economic development, and the prospects for economic and political reform. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: MUSI
title: Brains of Genius
long_title: Brains of Genius: Mozart and Friends
description: The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Picasso, and Joyce. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, memory, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: MUSI
title: Brains of Genius
long_title: Brains of Genius: Mozart and Friends
description: This section offered online.The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Picasso, and Joyce. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, memory, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: MUSI
title: Jazz and Race in America
description: A study of the evolution of jazz, from its precursors in the music of Africa through its beginnings in New Orleans to its fusion with rock in the 1970s . Jazz's greatest artists and their styles are presented with selected music of each jazz period and a discussion of the racial and sociological factors surrounding the genre's development. While no extensive music theory background or formal instrumental experience is required, students who can read music will be best prepared to fulfill the listening and form identification assignments. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: NHTL
title: Intensive Nahuatl Lang&Culture
description:
Offered at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, TN. Program dates: June 20  July 29, 2011. An intensive immersion course designed to familiarize students with modern and colonial Nahuatl. Beginning, intermediate and advanced level students may apply. Formal class hours are complemented with individual language practice sessions and group cultural activities. 3 Credits. Tuition $5,000. Partial scholarships are available. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Nashville. Housing in Vanderbilt University dormitories is available, for students wishing to stay on campus, at a cost of $945 per student for 42 nights, with two students per room. Students are free to make off-campus housing arrangements on their own. Meal Plan: Students may sign up for a meal plan that covers breakfast and lunch during the week at $15.68 per day or $470.40 for the 30 week days of the program; students will be responsible for dinners and weekend meals. The meal plan is optional. For questions regarding housing and meal plan, contact: Norma Antillón: norma.g.antillon@vanderbilt.edu or 615-322-2527. Details on the Yale Latin American and Iberian Studies website, http://www.yale.edu/macmillan/lais/summer.html
Or contact Jean Silk, jean.silk@yale.edu for further information.

subject: NURS
title: Clin Prac in Comm Hlth Nurs
long_title: Clinical Practice in Community Health Nursing
description: 3 credit hours. Community health nurses provide preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitation, and hospice services across the life span. The clinical experience focuses on the delivery of these health services in domestic community organizations. Nursing responsibility for caseload management offers an opportunity to interact with other members of the interdisciplinary health care team. A community-as-partner assessment and diagnosis project, which culminates in identification of a community health problem and potential solutions, augments core clinical practice. At the beginning of the following fall term, all students are required to present their community projects at a poster session. In addition, students at remote sites meet with the course coordinator at a time to be announced in the fall of the following term. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required for all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Sem in Comm Hlth Nur & PH
long_title: Seminar in Community Health Nursing and Public Health
description: 2 credit hours. Sessions explore the multidisciplinary theoretical foundations that are the basis for community health nursing practice across the life span. Topics include history of community health nursing and public health science; structure and function of federal, state, and local health organizations; funding mechanisms for community health care; epidemiological and biostatistical indicators of community health; methods of family and community analyses. Required for all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Clincial Prac. Adult Psych-MH

subject: NURS
title: Acute Care NP Summer Clinical
description: This elective study is initiated by the student and negotiated with faculty. The purpose is to allow in-depth pursuit of individual areas of interest and/or practice. A written proposal must be submitted and signed by the student, the faculty member(s), and the appropriate specialty director. Credit varies according to the terms of the contract.

subject: NURS
title: Ind Study in Abortion Care
description: This elective study is initiated by the student and negotiated with faculty. The purpose is to allow in-depth pursuit of individual areas of interest and/or practice. A written proposal must be submitted and signed by the student, the faculty member(s), and the appropriate specialty director. Credit varies according to the terms of the contract.

description: This elective study is initiated by the student and negotiated with faculty. The purpose is to allow in-depth pursuit of individual areas of interest and/or practice. A written proposal must be submitted and signed by the student, the faculty member(s), and the appropriate specialty director. Credit varies according to the terms of the contract.

subject: NURS
title: Adv Clin Prac for A/F/G&WH NPs
long_title: Adv Clin Prac for A/F/G&WH NPs

subject: NURS
title: Clinical Practicum for ONPs

subject: NURS
title: AdvancedSpecialtyPracticum II
description: 4.3 credit hours. The focus of this practicum is comprehensive management of a caseload of patients with students' elected special populations (cardiovascular, oncology). Emphasis is on prediction of common patient problems, formulation of management protocols, and generation of research questions. The practice sites in acute, ambulatory, and/or long-term settings provide an opportunity to observe system problems and develop clinical leadership strategies. Required for clinical nurse specialist students in the final year of specialization. Acute care nurse practitioner students must take 810c during the summer following 612b, unless they can demonstrate experience in caring for critically ill patients managed with complex technological interventions. Twelve hours of clinical practice plus one hour of clinical conference per week.
