subject: PHIL
title: Happiness
description: Historical and analytical inquiry into the meanings of happiness and their change over time. How new approaches to this topic in the social and natural sciences both complement and challenge time-honored philosophical and religious ideas. Whether happiness is a subjective and/or culturally relative idea. Whether happiness should be a goal in life. The relationship of happiness to other valued goods such as meaning, freedom, pleasure, virtue, and justice. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PHIL
title: Free Will, God, and Evil
description: An introduction to the philosophy of religion, focusing on the problem of evil: if there is an all-powerful and morally good God, then why is there so much evil in the world? Examination of attempts to reconcile the existence of God with evil by appealing to human free will. Such attempts raise other important philosophical questions: what is free will, and is it compatible with the laws of physics, or with divine providence? Why is freedom valuable? 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PHIL
title: First-Order Logic
description: An introduction to formal logic. Study of the formal deductive systems and semantics for both propositional and predicate logic. Some discussion of metatheory. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Ethics
description: Introduction to the field of ethics. Topics include the basis of morality, what a person is morally required to do for others, and what makes one act right and another wrong. Attention to theories associated with John Stuart Mill, Immanuel Kant, and Aristotle. Some consideration of how ethical theory can be applied to particular questions in society and in our personal lives. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PHIL
title: Eastern Philosophy
description: Introduction to Eastern philosophy through the study of philosophical and religious texts. Topics include reality and illusion, knowledge, self, right and wrong, nonattachment, meditation, aesthetics, the meaning of life, and death. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PHYS
title: Science of Modern Technology
description: Seminar that examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PHYS
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics
description: First part of a broad introduction, including the traditional parts of classical physics as well as selected topics in modern physics. Emphasis on fundamental principles, with examples of practical applications to medicine and other fields. Covers mechanics, thermodynamics, and wave motion. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Pre-college students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. PHYS 150 and 151 are normally taken in sequence. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics
description: Second part of a broad introduction, including the traditional parts of classical physics as well as selected topics in modern physics.  Emphasis on fundamental principles, with examples of practical applications to medicine and other fields. Covers electricity and magnetism, optics, and modern physics. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Pre-college students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. Prerequisite: PHYS 150 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics Laboratory
description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S170, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students only. Pre-college students with a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. 1/2 Credit. Tuition: $1,500. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics Laboratory
description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S171, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students only. Pre-college students with a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. 1/2 Credit. Tuition: $1,500. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PHYS
title: CANCELLED
long_title: University Physics for the Life Sciences
description: First part of a broad introduction, including the traditional parts of classical physics as well as selected topics in modern physics. Emphasis on fundamental principles and on applications drawn from the life sciences and medicine. Covers vectors, kinematics, Newton's laws of motion, oscillations and waves, gravitation, elasticity, statics, diffusion, fluids, and thermodynamics. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Pre-college students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. PHYS 170 and 171 are normally taken in sequence. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PHYS
title: CANCELLED
description: Second part of a broad introduction, including the traditional parts of classical physics as well as selected topics in modern physics. Emphasis on fundamental principles and on applications drawn from the life sciences and medicine. Covers electricity and magnetism, circuits, light and optics, sound, and modern physics. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Pre-college students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. Prerequisite: PHYS 170 or equivalent.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PHYS
title: University Physics
description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers Newtonian mechanics, gravitation, waves, and thermodynamics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.  May not be taken for credit after PHYS 170, 171. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PHYS
title: University Physics
description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers electromagnetism, optics, special relativity, and quantum physics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.  May not be taken for credit after PHYS 170, 171. Prerequisite: PHYS 180 or equivalent. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PLSC
title: Intro International Relations
description: A study of contemporary political issues that are international in scope: war, globalization, terrorism, human rights, immigration, development, and the environment. Topics include relations between states, international organizations such as the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund, and the World Bank, and nongovernmental bodies, including multinational corporations, nonprofit organizations, and armed groups. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PLSC
title: Intro-Political Philosophy
description: Issues of liberty, equality, and justice considered from within the Western tradition of political philosophy. Readings from Plato, Aristotle, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, Mill and contemporary authors. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PLSC
title: CANCELLED
description: Exploration of how violence and religion intersect historically, sociologically, and analytically. Comparative examination of religion and conflict over time and space. Focus on the major monotheistic religions, with some attention to classical polytheistic societies. Definitions of religious violence; whether religious violence is a different topic from religion and violence. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PLSC
title: Intn'lDimensionsDemocratizatn
description: Investigation of the role played by international factors such as socialization, coercion, and emulation in the current wave of democratizations around the world. Focus on the extent to which democratic processes can  be affected from the outside. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B July 4 - August 5

subject: PLSC
title: CANCELLED
description: Offered in Mexico City, Mexico. International human rights bodies and their implications for international politics. The role of human rights institutions in affording remedies to victims of state abuse. The emergence and exercise of international human rights law, including its nature, mechanisms, and logic. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Mexico, costs of room and board while in Mexico, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PLSC
title: The Cold War
description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4-August 5.

subject: PLSC
title: Institutns&ReprsentatnUSDmcrcy
long_title: Institutions and Representation in American Democracy
description: Ways in which institutions affect the functioning of democracy in the United States. Focus on representation of citizens' preferences in the public sphere. Institutions studied include primary elections, redistricting, campaign finance, early voting, multimember districts, pivotal politics, legislative committees, term limits, and term lengths. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PLSC
title: Journalism Liberalsm Democracy
description: The news media's role in configuring the democratic public sphere, from the early synergy of print capitalism and liberalism through the corporate consolidation of mass media and the recent fragmentation and fluidity of "news." Classical-humanist and civic-republican responses to these trends. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PLSC
title: Crime & Punishment
description: Topics in the history, theory, and realities of crime and punishment in the contemporary United States. Focus on various theories of criminal process in light of empirical evidence, the politicization of crime, civil rights issues, psychiatry and the law, abortion, and arguments about prison reform. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PLSC
title: The American Presidency
description: A survey of the historical development of the executive branch of the American national government; an examination of the politics of presidential leadership; and consideration of how the development of the executive branch has affected presidential politics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PLSC
title: Islamic Political Thought
description: Survey of major themes and concepts in Islamic political thought. Events and dynasties of the formative period. The building blocks of orthodox Islamic political thought, situated within the tradition of Islamic law. Examination of contemporary trends. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PLSC
title: Intro to Middle East Politics
description: An overview of politics in the Middle East and North Africa. State formation, the roles of religion and oil in politics, political institutions, economic development, and the prospects for economic and political reform. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PLSC
title: Intro to Middle East Politics
description: Offered online. An overview of politics in the Middle East and North Africa. State formation, the roles of religion and oil in politics, political institutions, economic development, and the prospects for economic and political reform. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PLSC
title: PoliticsofNationlism&Ethnicity
long_title: The Politics of Nationalism and Ethnicity
description: Study of contemporary work on ethnicity and nationalism from multiple disciplines and analytic traditions. Factors that make ethnicity and nationalism distinctive among social bases of political mobilization. Critical examination of the theory that nationalism is an exclusively modern phenomenon. Nationalism as an attempt to tie powerful organizations to specific territories and individual loyalties. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PLSC
title: Latin American Politics
description: Introduction to historical developments and fundamental political issues in Latin America. Overview of socioeconomic and political development since the discovery of the Americas, with a focus on key contemporary debates. Emphasis on the unique and innovative ways in which Latin American societies approach socioeconomic, political, and cultural conflicts such as military-civilian relationships, internal armed conflict, socioeconomic inequality, and respect for human rights. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PORT
title: Elem Port Romance Lang Speaker
long_title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages
description: Two weeks offered in New Haven, six weeks offered in Paraty and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in conjunction with PORT S122. A comprehensive Portuguese course for students proficient in Spanish or another Romance language. Basic vocabulary and fundamentals of grammar through practice in speaking, reading, and writing; conversational practice. Conducted entirely in Portuguese. Normally prepares for PORT 130. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janiero, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S352. Note that the course meets M-F, 9am-12pm in New Haven and M-F, 1pm-4pm in Paraty. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150.  Course Dates: June 6 - July 30.

subject: PORT
title: Elem Port Romance Lang Speaker
long_title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages
description: Two weeks offered in New Haven, six weeks offered in Paraty and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in conjunction with PORT S112. A comprehensive Portuguese course for students proficient in Spanish or another Romance language. Basic vocabulary and fundamentals of grammar through practice in speaking, reading, and writing; conversational practice. Conducted entirely in Portuguese. Normally prepares for PORT 130. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janiero, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S352. Note that the course meets M-F, 9am-12pm in New Haven and M-F, 1pm-4pm in Paraty. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150.  Course Dates: June 6 - July 30.

subject: PORT
title: Intermediate Portuguese
description: Two weeks offered in New Haven, six weeks offered in Paraty and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in conjunction with PORT S140. An intensive intermediate course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. An introduction to Brazilian cultural topics reflects the history and geography of the area. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janiero, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S352. Prerequisite: PORT 120, 122, 125 or equivalent For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150.  Course Dates: June 6 - July 30.

subject: PORT
title: Intermediate Portuguese
description: Two weeks offered in New Haven, six weeks offered in Paraty and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in conjunction with PORT S130. An intensive intermediate course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. An introduction to Brazilian cultural topics reflects the history and geography of the area. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janiero, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S352. Prerequisite: PORT 120, 122, 125 or equivalent For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150.  Course Dates: June 6 - July 30.

subject: PORT
title: Introduction to Brazil
description: Two weeks offered in New Haven, six weeks offered in Paraty and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. A comprehensive introduction to Brazilian cultural history, including formation, chronological development, and modern self-description. Cultural perspectives underlying current issues such as immigration, modernization, urbanization, race and ethnicity, the arts, literature, and national identity. Texts by major authors and figures in Brazilian literary, cultural, and intellectual history. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janiero, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S112/S122 or PORT S130/S140. Note that the course meets MW, 1pm-3pm in New Haven and MW, 4:30pm-6:30pm in Paraty. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: See PORT S112/S122 or PORT S130/S140 for tuition. Course Dates: June 6 - July 30.

subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Psychology
description: A survey of major psychological approaches to the biological, cognitive, social, and emotional bases of behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PSYC
title: Introduction Cognitive Science
description: Multidisciplinary approach to studying the nature of the mind. How the fields of philosophy, psychology, neuroscience, computer science, and linguistics contribute methods, theories, and research to addressing questions about how the mind works. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: PSYC
title: Developmental Psychology
description: Introduction to research and theory on the development and changes in perception, cognition, emotion and social functioning across the life span. Focus on birth through adulthood. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PSYC
title: Evolution and Cognition
description: How natural selection works and how it can be applied to the study of human psychology. Attention to research methods and findings. Topics include sex and mating, alliances, kinship, visual attention, spatial cognition and memory, and social exchange. May not be taken for credit after PSYC S171b. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: PSYC
title: Abnormal Psychology
description: Study of the major forms of psychopathology that appear in childhood and adult life. Topics include the symptoms of mental disorders; the etiology of disorders from a variety of perspectives (psychological, biological, and sociocultural); and issues pertaining to diagnosis and treatment. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1..

subject: REL
title: ElemBiblicalHebrew-Sumr Intnsv

subject: REL
title: ElemNTGreek-Summer Intensive

subject: REL
title: Leadership in Public Ministry

subject: REL
title: Summer Parish Minstry Intensve

subject: REL
title: Ecclesiastical Latin-Intensive

subject: REL
title: Catalysts for Social Progress

subject: RLST
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Jews, Christians, and Muslims on Genesis and Gender
description: Study of ancient Jewish, Christian, and Muslim interpretations of Genesis 1-3. Stories of creation and the "fall" of Adam as creatively reread in the biblical psalms, rabbinic midrash, New Testament writings, gnostic myth, the Qur'an, and early Islamic commentary. The influence of such interpretations on views of God, politics, society, and the human body. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: RLST
title: The Religion of Islam
description: Introduction to Islam. Arabia and the rise of Islam. Muhammad and the Qur'an. Muslim traditions and religious law. Basic beliefs and practices of the Muslim community. Islamic philosophy and theology. Shi'ism and Sufism. Religious institutions and modern trends. Jihad and fundamentalism. Religious freedom and democracy in Islam. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: RLST
title: CANCELLED
description: An inquiry into the possibility, nature, and purpose of Christian ethics through examination of principal positions developed in the Western church. The relationship of religion to ethics; sources of moral authority; the goals that constitute the good life. Authors include Adams, Augustine, Barth, Butler, Calvin, Gustafson, Kant, Kierkegaard, Luther, Plato, Thomas, and Yoder. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: RLST
title: Religion, War, and America
description: The relationship between religion and war in American history from colonial beginnings through Vietnam. The religious meaning of America, including the religious meanings of Americans at war; the mutually reinforcing influences of nationalism and religion; war as the norm of American national life; the concept of civil religion; biblical and messianic contexts of key U.S. conflicts. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: RLST
title: CANCELLED
description: From the garreting of Harriet Jacobs to Tyler Perry as Madea, this course introduces students to applied religious ethics through an exploration of black faith and sexuality in the United States. Students will learn basic foundational models for understanding religious ethics in philosophical, theological, and social terms while engaging the intersections of race, gender, sexuality, and faith. This course explores ethical frameworks functioning within cultural theory, historical accounts, film, and works of fiction. Students will be guided in a consideration of the roles of creativity and imagination in the formations of race, faith, and sexuality. Topics include sexual violence and exploitation, respectability and the black family, reclaiming the erotic, and new spiritualities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: RUSS
title: Second-Year Russian
description: First part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the second year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the first three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the last five weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S140 & RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150. Course dates: May 30 - July 25.

subject: RUSS
title: Second-Year Russian
description: Second part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the second year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the first three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the last five weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S130 & RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150. Course dates: May 30 - July 25.

subject: RUSS
title: Third-Year Russian
description: Second half offered in St. Petersburg, Russia. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the third-year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the first three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the last five weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S151 & RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Course dates: May 30 - July 25.

subject: RUSS
title: Third-Year Russian
description: Secon part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the third-year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the first three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the last five weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S150 & RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150. Course dates: May 30 - July 25.

subject: RUSS
title: Russian Culture
description: Second half offered in St. Petersburg, Russia. An interdisciplinary exploration of Russian cultural history through its art, architecture, theater, music, and film. Topics include conceptions of Russian nationhood; myths of St. Petersburg and Moscow; dissent and persecution; elites, intelligentsia, and attitudes toward the common people; conflicting appeals of rationality, spirituality, and idealism; the politicizing of personal life; and effects of Russian artistic innovations worldwide. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with either RUSS 130/140 or RUSS S150/151. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: see RUSS S130/140 or RUSS S 150/151.  Course Dates: May 30 - July 25.

subject: SAST
title: Bombay:City, SocietyandCulture
description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Critical introduction to contemporary Indian politics, society, culture, and religion through immersive study in Mumbai. Topics include urbanization, poverty, migration, housing, communal violence, caste segregation, class ghettoization, and popular culture. Must be taken in conjunction with SAST S364/LING S119. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from India, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,900. Session A: May 28- July 2.

subject: SAST
title: A Linguistic History of India
description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Study of the linguistic landscape of India, focusing particularly on the Indo-Aryan and Dravidian linguistic areas. The historical evolution of the multilingual landscape over time, and its political and social implications in contemporary India. Must be taken in conjunction with SAST S305/ANTH S305. Students are responsible for all travels expenses to and from India, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,900. Session A: May 28 - July 2.

subject: SCIE
title: Scientific Res: Process&Presen
description: This course is intended to provide comprehensive training and support to STARS students engaged in scientific research. Students will be introduced to the scientific process, including hypothesis testing, experimental design and data interpretation, through lectures, reading and discussions of the primary scientific literature. Skills development will emphasize the process of discussions of preparing written scientific reports and oral presentations highlighting effectual communication skills and the ability to interpret and display quantitative and qualitative informations. For STARS students only. Course may not be repeated for credit. 1 credit. Tuition: $3,ooo. June 6 - August 5.

subject: SOCY
title: IslamicSocietyCulture&Politics
description: The historical development of the global Muslim community, from its origins in seventh-century Arabia through its spread over subsequent centuries into the Middle East, Africa, Central and South/Southeast Asia, and the West. The tremendous variation and complexity expressed in society, culture, and politics across the Islamic world; Islam as a unifying factor on critical issues such as religious practice, political structure and activism, gender, and cultural expression. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: SOCY
title: Fndtns of Modern Social Theory
description: Major works of social thought that articulate the core ideas of sociology. Attention to social and historical contexts, conceptual frameworks and methods, and contributions to contemporary social analysis. Writers include Hobbes, Locke, J.S. Mill, Rousseau, Marx, Durkheim, and Weber. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: SOCY
title: Global Public Health
description: Introduction to public health issues and health development processes that are independent of national territorial boundaries but also incorporate the health needs and priorities of individual nation states. Mechanisms and challenges involved in incorporating the World Health Organization's commitment to primary health care with principles that currently dominate the global public health agenda. Sociological critique of public health interventions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: SOCY
title: Social Movements
description: Introduction to the sociological study of collective political protest. Different approaches to analyzing and making sense of such social movements, including their historical emergence as a modern form of public politics. How and why social movements develop, mobilize collective action, and decline. Case studies from the United States, China, and recent events in North Africa and the Middle East. Recommended preparation: an introductory course in sociology. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: SOCY
title: MulticulturalismOrderedSociety
description: Is there a link between social identity and crime?  What is the relationship among race, gender and perceptions of criminality?  What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime and criminal justice policy?  This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime and the criminal justice system.  Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories and debates.  Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration and unequal justice.  Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: SOCY
title: CANCELLED
description: Work is one of the defining experiences of modern social life, but what is it? Things like the structure of the labor market, professions, careers, and job status play major roles in our contemporary social lives, but why do these things take their current form? And where is work heading in the future? Using various sociological concepts and empirical studies, the course introduces students to these and other questions that define the meaning of work in contemporary social life. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 -July 1.

subject: SOCY
title: Culture of Southeastern Europe
description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study of southeastern Europe from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and postcommunist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with HIST S299. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 credit. Tuition: $2,900. Session B: July 2 - August 6.

subject: SPAN
title: Elementary Spanish I
description: For students who wish to begin study of the Spanish language. Development of basic skills in understanding, speaking, reading, and writing through a functional approach to the teaching of spanish grammar. Includes an introduction to the cultures (traditions, art, literature, music) of the Spanish-speaking world. Audio-visual materials are incorporated into class sessions. Conducted in Spanish. To be followed by SPAN S120.  Credit only on completion of SPAN S120. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: SPAN
title: Elementary Spanish ll
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Class sessions incorporate short authentic texts in Spanish, audiovisual materials, and film. Cultural topics of the Spanish-speaking world (traditions, art, literature, music) are included. Conducted in Spanish. After SPAN S110 or in accordance with placement results. Admits to SPAN 130 or 145. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish I
description: First part of an intensive "at home and abroad" course, designed to develop students' proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and presentation of cultural topics. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Bilbao, Spain (CRN 30239) or Quito, Ecuador (CRN 30243), costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S140 (in Bilbao, CRN 30240) or SPAN S140 (in Quito, CRN 30244) and S248 (Spain, 1936 to the Present) or S249 (Ecuador from Pre-Columbian Times to the Present). Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150. Bilbao course dates: May 30  July 26. Quito course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish I
description: First part of an intensive "at home and abroad" course, designed to develop students' proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and presentation of cultural topics. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Bilbao, Spain (CRN 30239) or Quito, Ecuador (CRN 30243), costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S140 (in Bilbao, CRN 30240) or SPAN S140 (in Quito, CRN 30244) and S248 (Spain, 1936 to the Present) or S249 (Ecuador from Pre-Columbian Times to the Present). Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150. Bilbao course dates: May 30  July 26. Quito course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish II
description: Offered in Bilbao, Spain (CRN 30240) or Quito, Ecuador (CRN 30244). Part 2 of an intensive "at home and abroad" course, designed to develop students' proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and videos; presentation of cultural topics. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Bilbao or Quito, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 (Bilbao CRN 30239, or Quito CRN 30243) and S248 (Bilbao) or S249 (Quito). Prerequisite: SPAN 130 (Intermediate Spanish I) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Bilbao course dates: May 30  July 26. Quito course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish II
description: Offered in Bilbao, Spain (CRN 30240) or Quito, Ecuador (CRN 30244). Part 2 of an intensive "at home and abroad" course, designed to develop students' proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and videos; presentation of cultural topics. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Bilbao or Quito, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 (Bilbao CRN 30239, or Quito CRN 30243) and S248 (Bilbao) or S249 (Quito). Prerequisite: SPAN 130 (Intermediate Spanish I) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Bilbao course dates: May 30  July 26. Quito course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: SPAN
title: Spain 1936 to Present
long_title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: History, Literature and Culture
description: Last four weeks offered in Bilbao, Spain. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Spain from the Civil War to the present. Use of a variety of materials, including literary texts, essays, film, television, music, and visual arts. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Bilbao, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/140. Course dates: May 30 - July 26.

subject: SPAN
title: Ecuador Pre-Columbian to Pres
long_title: Ecuador from Pre-Columbian Times to Present
description: Last four weeks offered in Quito, Ecuador. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Ecuador from Pre-Columbian times to the present. Presented through a variety of materials (literary texts, essays, films, music, visual arts). Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Quito, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/S140. Course dates: May 30 - July 23.

subject: STCY
title: Intro to the Study of the City
long_title: Introduction to the Study of the City
description: An examination of forces shaping American cities and strategies for dealing with them. Topics include housing, commercial development, parks, zoning, urban renewal, landmark preservation, new towns, and suburbs. Includes games, simulated problems, fieldwork, lectures, and discussion as well as field trips in New Haven and to New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: SWAH
title: Intermediate Kiswahili I
description: Offered at the Swahili Resource Centre in Mombasa, Kenya. Further development of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S140. Prerequisite: SWAH 120b (Elementary Kiswahili II) or equivalent. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Additional costs: $2,500 room and board in Kenya. Students are responsible for arranging travel and paying for airfare to and from Mombasa, as well as passport, visa, inoculations, and similar expenses. For further information contact the instructor at 203.432.9902 or at ann.biersteker@yale.edu.  Please also see www.yale.edu/macmillan/african. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $2,500. Course dates: May 28 -July 23.

subject: SWAH
title: Intermediate Kiswahili II
description: Offered at the Swahili Resource Centre in Mombasa, Kenya. Further development of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S130. Prerequisite: SWAH 130 (Intermediate Kiswahili I) or equivalent. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Additional costs: $2,500 room and board in Kenya. Students are responsible for arranging travel and paying for airfare to and from Mombasa, as well as passport, visa, inoculations, and similar expenses. For further information contact the instructor at 203.432.9902 or at ann.biersteker@yale.edu.  Please also see www.yale.edu/macmillan/african. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $2,500. Course Dates: May 28 - July 23.

subject: SWAH
title: Advanced Kiswahili
description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Development of fluency through readings and discussions on contemporary topics in Kiswahili, including its origins and spread to different parts of Eastern and Central Africa. The role of Kiswahili in addressing issues such as health and the environment. Introduction to literary criticism in Kiswahili. Materials include Kiswahili oral literature, prose, poetry, and plays, as well as texts drawn from popular and political culture. Prerequisite: SWAH 140b or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Kenya, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,000. Course dates: May 28 - July 9.

subject: THST
title: CANCELLED
description: This course explores the ways in which theater based processes have been used to facilitate learning, promote wellness, and address a variety of social concerns such as access to education and healthcare, poverty, gender-based violence, racism, and displacement. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: THST
title: Modern American Drama
description: In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: WGSS
title: Women, Food and Culture
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the gendering of food production, preparation, and consumption in cross-cultural perspective. Topics include agricultural practices, cooking, pasteurization, kitchen technology, food storage, home economics, hunger, anorexia, breast-feeding, meals, and ethnic identity. Class visits to Peabody Museum, Beinecke Library, Yale Farm and Yale University Art Gallery. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: WGSS
title: Reproductive Technologies
description: Introduction to scholarship on the anthropology of reproduction. Focus on reproductive technologies such as contraceptives, prenatal diagnostics, childbirth technologies, abortion, assisted reproduction, and reproductive technologies that engender harm, such as sex selection and female circumcision. The globalization of reproductive technologies, including social, cultural, legal, and ethical responses. Recommended preparation: ANTH 110b or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: WGSS
title: CANCELLED
description: Offered in Tokyo, Japan. Exploration of animation (anime) and graphic novels (manga) in contemporary Japan. Special attention to the social and historical contexts of the production and consumption of manga and anime and to themes of gender and sexuality found within. Includes visits to animation and manga studios and museums, fan conventions, the Cosplay scene, and Kyoto. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session B: July 2 - August 6.

subject: WGSS
title: CANCELLED
description: Cultural and historic constructions of masculinity explored through an investigation of male bodies, sexualities, and social interactions. Multiple masculinities; the relationship between hegemonic, nonhegemonic, and subordinate masculinities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: WGSS
title: CANCELLED
description: From the garreting of Harriet Jacobs to Tyler Perry as Madea, this course introduces students to applied religious ethics through an exploration of black faith and sexuality in the United States. Students will learn basic foundational models for understanding religious ethics in philosophical, theological, and social terms while engaging the intersections of race, gender, sexuality, and faith. This course explores ethical frameworks functioning within cultural theory, historical accounts, film, and works of fiction. Students will be guided in a consideration of the roles of creativity and imagination in the formations of race, faith, and sexuality. Topics include sexual violence and exploitation, respectability and the black family, reclaiming the erotic, and new spiritualities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: WGSS
title: CANCELLED
description: Theoretical, methodological, and aesthetic models in the field of critical ethnography, which seeks to understand and illustrate lived experiences of subjects who are differently situated in social webs of power. Models drawn mostly from race theory, postcolonial theory, queer theory, and feminisms. Problems of methodology, ethics, politics, and poetics that have an impact on students' own research practice. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
